verses.sanskrit:
arjuna uvāca
ye śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ |
teṣāṃ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
ye śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ |
teṣāṃ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: Those who worship (yajante) with faith (śraddhayānvitāḥ) but have abandoned scriptural injunction (śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya) — what is their standing (niṣṭhā), O Krishna? Is it sattva, rajas, or tamas?

word_breakdown.meaning: scriptural injunction / the rule of scripture

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's question here is one of the most practically relevant in the entire Gita. He has just heard Krishna say in Chapter 16 that scripture is the authority for determining right and wrong action. Now he asks: what about the countless sincere devotees across all traditions who worship from the heart but do not follow any formal scriptural system? Is their devotion worthless? Krishna's answer, unfolding across this entire chapter, is deeply compassionate — faith is real, and its quality is shaped by the nature (svabhāva) of the seeker. No sincere worship is without its fruit or standing.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This question bridges the end of Chapter 16, which concluded that scripture (śāstra) is the guide for determining proper action, with the practical reality that many people worship sincerely without following specific scriptural rules. Arjuna is not challenging the importance of scripture but rather asking where such heartfelt, unstudied devotion stands in the cosmic order. The three guṇas — sattva, rajas, and tamas — are the lens Krishna will use to answer. Every act of faith, worship, and devotion bears the stamp of the predominant guṇa in the devotee's nature.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's inquiry reflects a universal human experience: the sincere seeker who prays, worships, or meditates without formal religious training. Paramahansa Yogananda taught that God responds to the quality of devotion in the heart, not merely to ritual correctness. Yet Krishna's forthcoming answer shows that the guṇic makeup of the devotee shapes the very character of their faith — its object, its depth, and its fruit. The chapter is a compassionate mapping of where different types of faith lead, guiding the seeker toward the sāttvika path that ultimately elevates consciousness toward liberation.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's question arises from genuine concern for ordinary devotees who have deep faith but no formal scriptural grounding. Śrī Goyandka notes that this verse carries the inquiry: is natural, innate faith acceptable to God even without śāstra? Krishna's answer affirms that faith is never formless — it always takes a shape determined by one's intrinsic nature (svabhāva). The quality of that faith, whether sāttvika, rājasī, or tāmasī, determines what one worships, how one lives, and what results one obtains. The scriptures serve as a corrective and elevating guide precisely because natural faith, left ungoverned, may follow the lower guṇas.

verses.sanskrit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
tri-vidhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāva-jā |
sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śṛṇu ||
verses.transliteration:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
tri-vidhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāva-jā |
sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śṛṇu ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: The faith of embodied beings (dehināṃ) is threefold, born of one's own nature (svabhāva-jā) — sāttvikī, rājasī, and tāmasī. Hear about this from Me.

word_breakdown.meaning: of embodied beings / of those with bodies
born of one's own nature (svabhāva = inherent nature, jā = born)
of the nature of sattva / pure faith
of the nature of rajas / passionate faith
of the nature of tamas / inert/dark faith

commentary.dadaji: Krishna's opening answer is remarkably non-judgmental. He does not say that people without scriptural guidance have no valid faith — He says their faith is real but takes the color of their svabhāva, their inherent nature shaped by accumulated karma and guṇas. 'Svabhāva-jā' is the key: faith is not imposed from outside but arises organically from within. The three forms of faith — sāttvikī, rājasī, tāmasī — are not moral condemnations but accurate descriptions of where each person stands on their journey. Krishna's compassion lies in His recognition that even tamasic faith is faith, and it has its own progression.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The word 'svabhāva-jā' deserves deep contemplation. Svabhāva literally means 'one's own being' or 'inherent nature.' Faith is not acquired but emerges from what one already IS — the accumulated tendencies of countless lifetimes crystallized into one's current guṇic constitution. Swami Sarvapriyananda emphasizes that this verse does not prescribe but describes: Krishna is giving us a map of the territory of human faith. Understanding which type of faith predominates in oneself is itself a form of self-knowledge — and self-knowledge is the beginning of transformation.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that svabhāva — one's intrinsic nature — is the deposit of all past actions and thoughts, one's karmic inheritance. Faith, being the deepest orientation of the soul, naturally reflects this inheritance. The sāttvika person's faith is clear, directed toward light; the rājasika person's faith is intense but scattered toward worldly power and pleasure; the tāmasika person's faith is clouded and directed toward forces of inertia and darkness. Yet Yogananda would note that all three are seeds of the same divine impulse — the soul's search for its source — and all can be elevated through sādhana and grace.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka notes that Krishna uses the word 'śṛṇu' — 'hear' — signaling that what follows is important teaching requiring attentive listening. The fact that faith is 'svabhāva-jā,' born of nature, explains why mere external instruction is often insufficient to transform people: their faith runs deep in their constitution. This is why the Gita's prescription is not just intellectual knowledge but the gradual purification of one's svabhāva through sattvic action, worship, food, and austerity — which are the very topics of this chapter. Changing one's guṇic constitution changes the quality of one's faith and, therefore, of one's entire life.

verses.sanskrit:
sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata |
śraddhā-mayo'yaṃ puruṣo yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata |
śraddhā-mayo'yaṃ puruṣo yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ ||
verses.translation: The faith of each person is in accordance with their essential nature (sattvānurūpā), O Bhārata. This person is made of faith (śraddhā-mayaḥ); whatever one has faith in — that indeed one IS (yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: in accordance with one's sattva / nature (sattva + anurūpā = conforming to)
made of faith / constituted by faith

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most philosophically charged verses in the Gita. 'Yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ' — whatever one has deepest faith in, that one is. Faith is not a belief one holds; it is a reality one has become. If your deepest faith is in material pleasure, you have become a materialist at the level of being. If your deepest faith is in God, you are becoming divine. Dadaji often pointed to this verse as the basis for understanding why transformation must be at the level of śraddhā — one's most fundamental conviction — not merely at the level of behavior or thought. Deepest faith reshapes identity.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda highlights 'śraddhā-mayo'yaṃ puruṣaḥ' as one of the Gita's most penetrating psychological insights: the human being is not primarily a thinking animal or a desiring animal, but a faith-animal — constituted by what one fundamentally trusts, values, and believes to be real. Modern psychology speaks of core beliefs and deep values; the Gita goes deeper, pointing to śraddhā as the very substance of personhood. 'Yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ' is not just descriptive but prescriptive: to change who you are, change what you have faith in.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda understood this verse as the scriptural basis for the transformative power of devotion. If you habitually hold the thought and feeling 'I am a divine child of God, and God alone is real,' that śraddhā progressively reshapes your entire being. Conversely, habitual faith in limitation, fear, and material identity keeps one bound. Yogananda's teaching of affirmations and meditation is precisely this: consciously redirecting śraddhā toward the divine so that, according to Krishna's law, one becomes what one consistently has faith in. This verse is the metaphysical root of all spiritual practice.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka explains that 'sattva' in 'sattvānurūpā' refers not just to the guṇa sattva but to one's inner being or essential nature (antaḥkaraṇa). Faith mirrors the inner nature, and inner nature is itself built from accumulated habits of thought, feeling, and action. The statement 'yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ' is both a warning and an invitation: a warning because misplaced faith degrades the soul, and an invitation because rightly placed faith — in God, in righteousness, in liberation — elevates and ultimately transforms the entire being. Śraddhā in the Lord is the direct path to becoming like the Lord.

verses.sanskrit:
yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣa-rakṣāṃsi rājasāḥ |
pretān bhūta-gaṇāṃś cānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣa-rakṣāṃsi rājasāḥ |
pretān bhūta-gaṇāṃś cānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ ||
verses.translation: The sattvic worship the gods (devān); the rajasic worship yakṣas and rākṣasas; others — the tamasic — worship the departed (pretān) and hosts of elementals/spirits (bhūta-gaṇān).

word_breakdown.meaning: the sattvic ones / those of sattvic nature
yakṣas and rākṣasas (semi-divine power-beings and demons)
the rajasic ones / those of rajasic nature
the departed / ghosts / spirits of the dead
hosts of spirits / groups of elemental beings
the tamasic people / people of tamasic nature

commentary.dadaji: This verse maps the three levels of worship onto three planes of reality. Sattvic worshippers direct their faith upward — toward the devas, the luminous cosmic forces that uphold dharma and light. Rajasic worshippers seek power and wealth through propitiation of yakṣas (nature-spirits associated with wealth) and rākṣasas (forces of aggression and self-assertion). Tamasic worshippers, driven by fear and attachment to the dead, propitiate pretas and bhūta-gaṇas. The quality of one's worship reveals the quality of one's soul. One does not need to look at what someone professes to believe — watch what they actually sacrifice their time, energy, and resources upon: that is their true worship.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that yakṣas in Indian tradition are associated with worldly wealth (Kubera, the god of wealth, is their king), and rākṣasas with raw power and dominance. Rajasic religion, then, is essentially transactional and power-oriented: worship in order to gain wealth, status, victory over enemies. This is very much alive in contemporary religious practice — prayers and rituals performed to gain material advantage. Tamasic worship of pretas and bhūtas reflects religion rooted in fear — fear of the dead, fear of spirits — which motivates propitiatory rites. Only sattvic worship is genuinely uplifting, oriented toward the luminous and the transcendent.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda saw this verse as a teaching about where one's attention habitually goes. The 'devas' are not merely mythological beings but principles of light, truth, and cosmic order — the sattvic person worships these principles in their outer religious life and in their inner life of meditation. The rajasic person, though perhaps performing religious rituals, is inwardly worshipping their own ambitions, desires for power, and competitive ego. The tamasic person is bound by dread of dark forces and ancestral obligations rooted in fear rather than love. True worship, Yogananda taught, is the complete offering of one's consciousness to the Divine.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka points out that this classification is not about which religion one belongs to but about the inner attitude underlying any religious practice. A person in any tradition can worship with sattvic intent — directed toward the highest light and truth — or with rajasic intent (seeking material gain through religious means), or with tamasic intent (driven by superstition and fear). The Gita is not condemning specific religious communities but discerning the inner quality of devotion. The implication is clear: one should examine one's own worship and ask, 'Am I approaching God to give, to surrender, and to love — or to get something for myself?'

verses.sanskrit:
aśāstra-vihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ |
dambhāhaṅkāra-saṃyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
aśāstra-vihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ |
dambhāhaṅkāra-saṃyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ ||
verses.translation: Those who practice terrible (ghora) austerities not enjoined by scripture (aśāstra-vihitam), combined with ostentation (dambha) and ego (ahaṅkāra), and impelled by desire (kāma), passion (rāga), and force (bala)...

word_breakdown.meaning: not sanctioned by scripture (a = not, śāstra = scripture, vihitam = enjoined/prescribed)

commentary.dadaji: This verse begins a two-verse description (completed in verse 6) of perhaps the most dangerous form of misguided spirituality: extreme asceticism motivated not by love of God or genuine renunciation, but by ego, desire for recognition, and passionate will. 'Dambha' is spiritual vanity — performing austerities to be seen, to build a reputation as a great ascetic. 'Ahaṅkāra' is the deep ego-identification that makes the person feel their severe practices set them above others. 'Kāma-rāga-bala' reveals the true drivers: underneath the appearance of renunciation lies intense desire, passion, and the violence of forceful will.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that the Gita here specifically targets austerities that are 'aśāstra-vihita' — not prescribed by scripture. The scriptures prescribe austerities in right measure, with right motive, and in a way that purifies without destroying. Going beyond these in the name of greater renunciation, when actually driven by ego and desire for spiritual status, is the very opposite of genuine tapas. The five qualities listed — dambha, ahaṅkāra, kāma, rāga, bala — are all forms of the same fundamental error: the ego asserting itself even through the vehicle of apparent self-denial.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda was emphatic that true spiritual austerity is defined by inner detachment and love for God, not by physical severity. He often taught that extreme self-mortification, unless divinely guided, produces pride rather than humility and agitation rather than peace. The five qualities described here — ostentation, ego, desire, passion, force — are exactly what excessive, ego-driven asceticism produces and feeds. Yogananda recommended the 'middle path' of balanced, scriptural austerity that gradually purifies without breaking the instrument of body and mind needed for God-realization.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka emphasizes that the fundamental problem with the practices described in this verse is their motivation. Tapas (austerity) in itself is valuable and necessary — the entire Gita recommends it. But when it is performed with 'dambhāhaṅkāra-saṃyuktāḥ' — combined with showmanship and ego — and 'kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ' — driven by underlying desire, passion, and forceful willfulness — it becomes inverted: the outward form of renunciation concealing inward attachment and pride. Such practices not only fail to purify but actively strengthen the very tendencies they appear to combat.

verses.sanskrit:
karśayantaḥ śarīra-sthaṃ bhūta-grāmam acetasaḥ |
māṃ caivāntaḥ śarīra-sthaṃ tān viddhy āsura-niścayān ||
verses.transliteration:
karśayantaḥ śarīra-sthaṃ bhūta-grāmam acetasaḥ |
māṃ caivāntaḥ śarīra-sthaṃ tān viddhy āsura-niścayān ||
verses.translation: ...senselessly (acetasaḥ) tormenting the elements/beings dwelling within the body, and also Me who am seated within the body — know them to be of demoniac resolve (āsura-niścayān).

word_breakdown.meaning: dwelling in the body (śarīra = body, stha = abiding)
the collection of elements / all the beings/constituents that compose the body
of demoniac resolve / with demonic determination (āsura = demonic, niścaya = resolve/certainty)

commentary.dadaji: The culminating phrase of this two-verse passage is electrifying: 'māṃ caivāntaḥ śarīra-stham' — and they also torment ME who dwell within the body. This is Krishna's most personal objection to extreme self-mortification. It is not simply that such practices are unhealthy or unsound — they actually injure the Lord's own dwelling place. The body is the temple of the Divine. To abuse it in the name of spirituality is a contradiction: one claims to seek God while attacking the very home in which God resides. 'Āsura-niścayān' — of demoniac resolve — is a severe verdict that connects back to Chapter 16's description of the āsurī nature.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that 'bhūta-grāmam' — the collection of elements or beings within the body — refers to the five elements and the prāṇas, the very constituents of life itself. Acetasaḥ — 'senselessly' or 'without consciousness' — is the key qualifier: such people torment the body without understanding what the body actually is: a temporary home of the ātman and a vehicle for mokṣa. The body is not the enemy; tamasic and rajasic conditioning of the mind is the enemy. 'Tān viddhy āsura-niścayān' — know them to be of demoniac resolve — is a direct cross-reference to Chapter 16, uniting the themes of that chapter with this one.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda was deeply moved by the phrase 'māṃ caivāntaḥ śarīra-stham' — 'Me also, who dwell within the body.' He taught that the body is the temple of God, housing not only the ātman but also the divine life-force (prāṇa) that is itself an expression of the Divine. Extreme self-mortification that destroys health and vitality is not spirituality but a form of violence against God's own creation and dwelling place. Genuine tapas purifies and strengthens the body-mind instrument; it does not shatter it. Yogananda's path of Kriya Yoga is precisely a balanced, scientific austerity that refines rather than destroys.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka observes that 'āsura-niścayān' — demoniac resolve — is a strong and precise term. The āsura does not lack determination or effort; the āsura lacks right knowledge and right motive. These extreme ascetics have resolve and effort in abundance — but it is resolve in service of ego and inverted desire, not genuine surrender to God. This makes them more dangerous than ordinary worldly people, because they use the outer forms of spirituality to camouflage deep-seated ego-assertion. The Gita's verdict is compassionate but clear: such practices, no matter how impressive outwardly, lead in the opposite direction from liberation.

verses.sanskrit:
āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ |
yajñas tapas tathā dānaṃ teṣāṃ bhedam imaṃ śṛṇu ||
verses.transliteration:
āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ |
yajñas tapas tathā dānaṃ teṣāṃ bhedam imaṃ śṛṇu ||
verses.translation: And even the food (āhāra) that is dear to each person is of three kinds; likewise sacrifice (yajña), austerity (tapas), and charity (dāna) are also threefold. Hear about these distinctions (bhedam).

commentary.dadaji: This transitional verse is the pivot of the chapter. Having established that faith is threefold (v2-4), and having described misguided austerity (v5-6), Krishna now announces that He will analyze four more domains through the three-guṇa lens: food (āhāra), sacrifice (yajña), austerity (tapas), and charity (dāna). These four cover nearly the entire range of practical human life — what you eat, what you worship, how you discipline yourself, and how you give. The repetition of 'śṛṇu' (hear) signals again that what follows is teaching of special importance.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes the profound inclusiveness of this verse: even food preferences — something as apparently mundane as what one likes to eat — are not random or neutral, but express and reinforce one's guṇic constitution. The Gita treats nothing in human life as trivial; every choice, even dietary, is a spiritual datum. Yajña (sacrifice/worship), tapas (austerity), and dāna (charity) are the three pillars of traditional Indian religious life. Krishna will show that each can be performed in sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic modes — and the mode determines the fruit.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught extensively about the spiritual dimension of diet, rooted in precisely this Gita teaching. Food carries vibration — the prana in food affects the consciousness of the eater. This is why Yogananda emphasized a sattvic vegetarian diet as a foundation for meditation practice. But he also emphasized that all four categories here — food, worship, self-discipline, and giving — must be brought into the sattvic mode for holistic spiritual growth. A person can meditate daily (sattvic worship) but eat tamasically and find their practice undermined; all aspects of life are interconnected in the Gita's vision.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka points out that the four categories of this verse — āhāra, yajña, tapas, dāna — constitute the four pillars of practical dharmic life. Food sustains the body; sacrifice maintains the cosmic order and connection with the divine; austerity purifies the inner instrument; charity expresses and cultivates love for all beings. The fact that each of these can be sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic means that genuine spiritual life requires the purification of all four domains simultaneously. Attending to one while neglecting the others creates imbalance. The Gita here offers a comprehensive checklist for self-assessment.

verses.sanskrit:
āyuḥ-sattva-balārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ |
rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārāḥ sāttvika-priyāḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
āyuḥ-sattva-balārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ |
rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārāḥ sāttvika-priyāḥ ||
verses.translation: Foods that increase lifespan (āyus), purity of mind (sattva), strength (bala), health (ārogya), happiness (sukha), and delight (prīti) — which are juicy (rasyāḥ), smooth/oleaginous (snigdhāḥ), substantial (sthirāḥ), and pleasant to the heart (hṛdyāḥ) — these are dear to the sattvic.

word_breakdown.meaning: pleasing to the heart / agreeable / wholesome
dear to the sattvic / preferred by those of sattvic nature

commentary.dadaji: Notice the richness of this verse: sattvic food promotes six qualities — āyus (long life), sattva (clarity), bala (strength), ārogya (health), sukha (wellbeing), and prīti (inner joy and love). It possesses four sensory qualities — rasyā (juicy, full of life-essence), snigdha (smooth and nourishing), sthira (firm and sustaining), hṛdya (naturally agreeable). This is food that is alive, fresh, naturally sweet, and genuinely nourishing — food that satisfies the body without agitating the mind. Sattvic diet is not about rigid rules but about choosing what supports life, clarity, and inner peace.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that 'rasa' in 'rasyāḥ' has a deeper meaning than 'juicy' — it refers to the essence or life-force present in fresh, vital food. 'Snigdha' — smooth and oleaginous — refers to properly prepared foods with good fats that nourish the tissues. 'Sthira' — firm and substantial — means food that provides lasting nourishment rather than quick stimulation followed by a crash. 'Hṛdya' — pleasing to the heart — suggests that sattvic food is naturally agreeable to a balanced constitution, not craved through artificial stimulation of the taste buds. This is the ancient Ayurvedic vision of food as medicine for body, mind, and soul.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda frequently cited this verse as the Gita's nutritional guidance. He taught that fresh fruits, vegetables, grains, legumes, dairy, and natural sweeteners are the sattvic foods par excellence. These six benefits — āyus, sattva, bala, ārogya, sukha, prīti — are exactly what a meditator needs: longevity to complete the spiritual journey, mental clarity for sustained meditation, physical strength for spiritual practice, health to avoid distraction by illness, happiness as the natural mood of a balanced mind, and prīti (love and delight) as the emotional tone of the devotee. Diet and consciousness are intimately linked.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka emphasizes that the six benefits of sattvic food span the full spectrum of human well-being: āyus (physical lifespan), sattva (mental quality), bala (physical energy), ārogya (absence of disease), sukha (experiential happiness), and prīti (the subtler joy of love and contentment). This is not a diet for physical health alone but a diet for integrated well-being at every level. The four qualities — rasyā, snigdha, sthira, hṛdya — describe food that is genuinely nourishing rather than merely stimulating. Such food promotes the inner quiet and clarity that make meditation and self-knowledge possible.

verses.translation: Foods that are bitter (kaṭu), sour (amla), salty (lavaṇa), excessively hot (aty-uṣṇa), pungent (tīkṣṇa), dry (rūkṣa), and burning (vidāhī) — these are dear to the rajasic (rājasasyeṣṭāḥ); they produce pain (duḥkha), grief (śoka), and disease (āmaya).

commentary.dadaji: The seven qualities of rajasic food are all modes of excess and intensity: excessively bitter, sour, salty, hot, sharp, dry, and burning. These are not intrinsically forbidden tastes — bitter, sour, and salty are part of the Ayurvedic six tastes — but it is the excess and habitual preference for such stimulation that marks rajas. The rajasic person is always seeking more stimulation, sharper sensations, stronger experiences. This extends from food to entertainment, relationships, and ambition. The consequence — 'duḥkha-śoka-āmaya-pradāḥ' — is striking: physical pain, emotional grief, and physical disease, all arising from the over-stimulated, inflamed constitution.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that Ayurveda and the Gita agree on this analysis: excessively stimulating food creates āma (toxic residue), aggravates pitta (the fire principle), and disturbs vāta (the air principle), leading to both physical disease and mental agitation. The emotional consequences — duḥkha (physical pain) and śoka (mental grief) — reveal the mind-body connection: an agitated digestive system agitates the nervous system and mind, creating anxiety, irritability, and emotional volatility. The rajasic person eats for the stimulation of taste rather than for genuine nourishment, just as they act for the stimulation of results rather than for genuine service.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that overly spiced, fried, heavily salted, and processed foods fall into the rajasic category. Such foods excite the senses and the passional nature, making calm meditation difficult. He observed that people who habitually eat very spicy or stimulating food find their minds more prone to agitation, anger, and restlessness. This is not a rigid prohibition but a recognition of cause and effect: rajasic food feeds rajasic consciousness. For those on the spiritual path seeking inner stillness, gradually moving toward sattvic food — while not becoming fanatical about it — supports the meditative life.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka clarifies that the problem with rajasic foods is not the tastes themselves (bitter, sour, salty, hot are all natural and present in sattvic foods in balanced measure) but the excess and the habitual craving for stimulation. 'Aty-uṣṇa' — excessively hot — is the key qualifier. Rajas is always about excess and intensity. The three results — duḥkha (pain), śoka (sorrow), āmaya (disease) — correspond to three levels: physical, emotional, and pathological. Rajasic diet ultimately produces suffering at all three levels, even if it provides temporary pleasure and stimulation. This teaching supports the practice of mitāhāra — moderation in food.

verses.sanskrit:
yāta-yāmaṃ gata-rasaṃ pūti paryuṣitaṃ ca yat |
ucchiṣṭam api cāmedhyaṃ bhojanaṃ tāmasa-priyam ||
verses.transliteration:
yāta-yāmaṃ gata-rasaṃ pūti paryuṣitaṃ ca yat |
ucchiṣṭam api cāmedhyaṃ bhojanaṃ tāmasa-priyam ||
verses.translation: Food that is stale (yāta-yāmam), tasteless/devoid of essence (gata-rasam), putrid/rotten (pūtī), day-old/leftover (paryuṣitam), impure remnants (ucchiṣṭam), and ritually impure (amedhyam) — such food is dear to the tamasic.

word_breakdown.meaning: stale / time-passed (yāta = passed, yāma = a period of three hours; food past its prime)
devoid of taste/essence (gata = gone, rasa = essence/taste/life-force)
day-old / leftover / stale from previous day
remnants / leftovers / food touched and left by another
impure / ritually unclean / unfit for sacred use
dear to the tamasic / preferred by those of tamasic nature

commentary.dadaji: Tamasic food is food from which life has departed. 'Yāta-yāmam' — time-passed — refers not just to old food but to the concept that food has a life-span: fresh food is vibrant with prāṇa, and as time passes, that prāṇa dissipates. 'Gata-rasam' — from which rasa has gone — is the perfect image: rasa is both taste and the subtle life-essence that nourishes consciousness. Stale, rotten, leftover food may fill the stomach but does not nourish the soul. The person who habitually prefers such food — and is content with it — reveals a consciousness that has become indifferent to quality, vitality, and purity.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that 'amedhyam' — ritually impure — carries a broader meaning than mere ceremonial uncleanliness. It refers to food that is unfit to offer to the divine, and since one's own body is the temple of the divine, what one eats is in a sense an offering to the Lord within. Tamasic food insults this inner temple. 'Ucchiṣṭam' — remnants left by others — is specifically food that carries another's energetic imprint after being partially consumed, considered spiritually depleting. The overall picture is of a person who has given up on quality entirely — who feeds the body without any attention to what nourishes the mind and soul.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that food is not merely biochemical fuel but a carrier of prāṇa — subtle life-energy. This is why he emphasized fresh, freshly cooked, wholesome food. Tamasic food — stale, rotten, processed, devitalized — contains little or no prāṇa and actually weighs down the consciousness with inertia, dullness, and sleep. The person who habitually eats such food finds their mind heavy, their thoughts sluggish, and their spiritual aspiration dampened. 'Gata-rasam' — from which the rasa has gone — perfectly describes modern processed food: it may taste artificially flavored but is devoid of the subtle life-essence that genuine food carries.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka observes that this verse's description of tamasic food goes beyond physical spoilage to address the energetic and spiritual dimension of food. 'Yāta-yāmam' establishes the principle that food has a temporal quality — its prāṇa diminishes with time. 'Gata-rasam' establishes that what we seek in food is not just calories but rasa — the quintessence of nourishment. Tamasic food has lost both. The result of habitually eating such food is the reinforcement of tamas in the mind — heaviness, sloth, dullness, indifference, and an inability to aspire toward the higher. Just as sattvic food feeds the light in consciousness, tamasic food feeds the darkness.
